ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a ton about fossils!

Lots of hands-on knowledge to supplement what you learn in lecture. Learned about life from all parts of Earth's history, from before even the Paleozoic into the modern. Gained a better understanding of ecosystems and fossilization.

I learned how to be a better observer. I also gained a lot of knowledge about taphonomy (the process of fossilization) and what the fossil record has looked like over time. This was a great class today concurrently with the lecture section, and the labs really reinforced the information.
Development of critical thinking to extrapolate knowledge of ancient ecology from the limited data provided in the fossil record

Practical experience with fossils - understanding what we're looking at when we see a fossil and how to interpret things from the physical fossil, like how it was preserved, when it might be from, what it might represent, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: not a lot of feedback or guidance -- it's almost all hands on learning. this can be fun but it also is a bit unsettling the first couple sections when you feel like you have zero clue as to what's going on and how to approach things. the specimens are all really interesting but it's very much a different form of learning than I have been used to.

The materials you get to handle in this course are incredible; there are few other opportunities in life to see and touch the things you do in this lab. Doing things hands-on really helps you get a better sense of the lecture material. At times labs can feel like they're dragging on, and you usually feel pretty spent at the end of the session, but that's what you get with a three-hour-long lab. If anything, the design makes the three hours go by faster than they otherwise would. It's great having unstructured time within that three hours to talk to the professor; that may be where I learned the most. These guys really are incredible and it's nice being able to talk to them about anything paleontological or otherwise.

The first section of the lab (the first couple labs) were quite difficult. It was hard to answer a lot of the questions with zero geology/paleontology background. By the end of the lab, I felt much stronger in my knowledge of fossils, and was therefore much more confident in completing the lab questions. I really enjoyed the variety of fossils we had the chance to examine (Yales collections are awesome!), though sometimes labs could run a little long.

Strengths: Very cool subject material and the teachers were generally good.
Weaknesses: kind of grueling and long. I spent more hours in class each week for this half credit than I did for any of my full-credit classes this semester.

Would appreciate some more direction and hands-on instruction from the professors than just being handed the specimens and lab sheets and being told to go for it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! if you're taking History of Life then DEFINITELY take this course! I would have been so so lost in lecture without this lab. it's also really nice to have more time to get to know the professors because they're all lovely
Yeah! If you have any interest in paleontology, I think it's a wonderful addition to History of Life.
I would recommend taking this class to reinforce the EPS 125 lecture content, and its a good choice for the EVST lab science requirement.
Yeah, I think so, unless you're not interested in fossils. It was cool but long.

extras.title: EPS 126L 01 - Lab for the History of Life
